blocks.text:
First week-end in June - a trip to Highlands, N. J. with Ve and Bill Huber to visit Ann and Ed Coe. Rain almost constantly for the two days.
We drove over via Philadelphia and Trenton; and returned through New Brunswick, Flemington and New Hope. On Sunday we took a drive down the coast as far as Asbury Park.
Pictures show Ed's boat in dry-dock; and an almost deserted Asbury Park.
NANCY ANN

pages.full_text:

We drove over via Philadelphia and Trenton; and returned through New Brunswick, Flemington and New Hope. On Sunday we took a drive down the coast as far as Asbury Park.
Pictures show Ed's boat in dry-dock; and an almost deserted Asbury Park.

blocks.text: Boating from the cottage was one of the chief recreations. We had access to a rowboat at all times. The motor boat belonged to the Elliott boy across the road.

blocks.text:
On Wednesday of our week at Webster Lake, Kitty and Gordon made a one day trip through the White Mountains, which we had not visited since 1936. Departure at 6 A. M. Return about 5 P. M. Route shown on the map below.
[The rest is obscured by cropping.]
St.Johnsbury Lower Waterford E.Peacham E.Barnet N.Harris
Randolph
Meadows Rd.
W. Canaan Lockheaven
Northfield
Waterloo
Kitty looks to the mountains in the Waterville Valley region.

blocks.text: Beautiful falls along the highway as we near Franconia Notch.
Old Man of the Mountains," "The Great Stone Face", immortalized by Hawthorne.
Crawford Notch with the rippling Saco River - one of most famous mountain passes in the East.

blocks.text: Perhaps the most interesting part of our trip through the White Mountains was tra-versing the side road over the mountains from Bartlett to Passaconaway; and then following Swift River to Conway; and then unlike most white Mountain roads which run at the foot of this mountain, this road takes you over the mountains. Many of the views are spectacular. Rock filled Swift River offers many inviting picnic spots. Only at one or two points along Swift River was the road bad, and here it appeared that rock slides had recently been removed.
Dense woodland on both sides of road.
A pause to enjoy the woodland setting on the long climb over the mountains.
Along rock filled Swift River as we approach Conway.

pages.full_text:
Perhaps the most interesting part of our trip through the White Mountains was tra-versing the side road over the mountains from Bartlett to Passaconaway; and then following Swift River to Conway; and then unlike most white Mountain roads which run at the foot of this mountain, this road takes you over the mountains. Many of the views are spectacular. Rock filled Swift River offers many inviting picnic spots. Only at one or two points along Swift River was the road bad, and here it appeared that rock slides had recently been removed.

Dense woodland on both sides of road.

A pause to enjoy the woodland setting on the long climb over the mountains.

Along rock filled Swift River as we approach Conway.

blocks.text: Meredith Bay with Lake Winnipesaukee in the distance, seen from Meredith. Winnipesaukee is New Hampshire's largest lake, with 72 square miles of water surface and 274 habitable islands. Summer homes and tourist cabins are everywhere along the lake front.
End - one day trip through White Mountains.

pages.full_text:
Meredith Bay with Lake Winnipesaukee in the distance, seen from Meredith. Winnipesaukee is New Hampshire's largest lake, with 72 square miles of water surface and 274 habitable islands. Summer homes and tourist cabins are everywhere along the lake front.

End - one day trip through White Mountains.

blocks.text: Harrisburg
Wheeling
Springfield
Harrisonburg
Charleston

Buses lined up before the Biltmore (our hotel) to take the delegates to the airfield. We were the first civilian group since the War to be accorded this privilege. Here we saw our first "jet" plane in flight.

blocks.text: July 24, 1947 - Picnic at Sam and Marion Rohrher's for Bob and Charlotte Herr, visitors from Panama.

Time Marches On! Picture at the left was taken in 1939, when the Herrs made a previous trip to the States. The Rohrers and the Riekers had one child each. The large picture above shows a total accumulation of ten children in the intervening eight years. Large picture, standing: Bob Herr, Dottie Rieker, Gordon, Marion Rohrer, Louise Davis; seated, second row: Barbara Rieker, Chrissy Rohrer, Babe Rieker, Kitty, Charlotte Herr holding Louise, John Davis; seated on ground: Kathy, David Rieker, Billy Rohrer, Charlotte Ann Herr, Nancy, Cindy, Judy Rohrer.
The children - ten of them.

blocks.text: Seventeen Members of Lancaster ABC Attend the District Picnic at Reading. August 20, 1947.
Heller, Robinson, Bassett, Rohrer, Vanderslice, Nolt, Smith, Huber.
Gordon took advantage of a free airplane ride. Air views of Reading at an altitude of about 2,000 feet.

Claude Smith, Bob Vanderslice, Sam Rohrer,
Bill Robinson and Lloyd Nolt.
Bill Huber and Bill Robinson try to beat a one armed bandit.

blocks.text: August 30, 1947 - Accompanied by Laurence and Annemarie Strickler, Al and Dottie Adee, we visit Walter and Mabel Reisner at their home in Wynnewood. Pictures taken on the terrace of the Reisner home.

blocks.text: Labor Day, 1947. Picnic along the Little Conestoga with the Hubers and the Rohrers.
Off to Milton J. B. Brecht School on the Lititz Pike after Labor Day. Nancy to third grade, Cindy to first. A school bus will pick them up at the corner.
One of Lancaster County's well kept farms. Farmers are prospering with income more than double pre-war.
